insects.name: Colorado Potato Beetle
insects.effect: Larvae and adults defoliate foliage, reducing yield by 30–50% if unmanaged.

insects.name: Potato Tuber Moth
insects.effect: Larvae mine leaves, stems, and tubers; in storage, can cause up to 100% tuber loss.

insects.name: Potato Leafhopper
insects.effect: Sap‑sucking causes 'hopperburn'—leaf curling, necrosis, and up to 75% yield loss.

solution: Rotate with non‑host crops to reduce Colorado potato beetle pressure :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.
Hand‑destroy egg masses and larvae; apply systemic/contact insecticides when thresholds reached :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
Monitor for leafhoppers with sweep nets and spray insecticides (e.g. carbaryl) when hopperburn appears :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.

insects.name: Western Corn Rootworm
insects.effect: Larvae feed on roots, causing lodging and reduced yield; adults feed on silks, impacting pollination.

insects.name: Corn Leaf Aphid
insects.effect: Dense colonies suck sap, produce honeydew impairing pollination and can reduce yields up to 90%.

insects.name: Maize Stalk Borer
insects.effect: Larvae damage leaf funnels and stalks; tunneling can lead to fungal infection and major yields loss (20–100%).

solution: Rotate crops and delay planting to disrupt western corn rootworm cycle :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.
Scout aphids in tassels; control outbreaks early to prevent honeydew buildup :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.
Apply push–pull cultural strategy or biological control agents against stalk borer :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.

insects.name: Rice Water Weevil
insects.effect: Larvae feed on roots, reducing stand vigor and yield.

insects.name: Rice Gall Midge
insects.effect: Larvae cause 'silver shoots' (galls), stunting tiller growth and preventing panicle formation.

insects.name: Brown Planthopper
insects.effect: Sucks sap, causing hopperburn and transmitting grassy stunt and ragged stunt viruses.

solution: Implement water‐management (periodic mid‑season drainage) to reduce water weevil populations.
Plant resistant or tolerant varieties (e.g., IR64) to manage brown planthopper outbreaks :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.
Use integrated pest management tactics (monitoring, biological control, judicious insecticide use) to suppress gall midge :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.

insects.name: Wheat Stem Sawfly
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel stems causing lodging, reduced grain fill, and yield losses up to 25%.

insects.name: Russian Wheat Aphid
insects.effect: Sap‑sucking causes leaf rolling, bleaching, stunted growth, and reduced yield.

insects.name: Armyworm
insects.effect: Chews foliage and heads, reducing biomass and grain quality.

solution: Plant resistant varieties (solid-stem) to reduce stem sawfly damage :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.
Monitor aphid populations and apply insecticide only if economic thresholds are exceeded :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.
Scout regularly for armyworm; treat with foliar insecticides if defoliation threatens crop health :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.

insects.name: Soybean Aphid
insects.effect: Colonies suck sap, causing yellowing and reduced pod set; can spread plant diseases.

insects.name: Bean Leaf Beetle
insects.effect: Chews foliage and pods, reducing yield and allowing entry for pathogens.

insects.name: Stink Bug Complex
insects.effect: Feeds on pods causing discoloration, shriveled seeds, and yield loss.

solution: Scout weekly with drop cloth during bloom/pod-fill; apply insecticide if aphid thresholds are exceeded :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.
Monitor for beetle feeding; target insecticide applications when defoliation or pod feeding is observed :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.
Treat stink bugs when counts exceed 1 per row-foot during pod-fill stage :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.

insects.name: Bollworm
insects.effect: Larvae bore into bolls, damaging fibers and reducing lint quality.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Sap-sucking causes curled leaves and transmits viral diseases.

insects.name: Whitefly
insects.effect: Feeds on underside of leaves, excreting honeydew leading to sooty mold.

solution: Deploy Bt cotton varieties to control bollworm larvae.
Release natural enemies like ladybird beetles and parasitic wasps against aphids and whiteflies.
Monitor with pheromone traps and apply selective insecticides only at economic thresholds.

insects.name: Asian Citrus Psyllid
insects.effect: Vectors Huanglongbing (citrus greening), causing yellow shoots and dieback.

insects.name: Citrus Leafminer
insects.effect: Larvae mine leaf tissue, causing curling and reduced photosynthesis.

insects.name: Citrus Thrips
insects.effect: Damages fruit surface and causes scarring reducing marketability.

solution: Control psyllids with foliar insecticides timed to flush cycles and remove symptomatic trees.
Use horticultural oils to suppress leafminer eggs and larvae.
Encourage predatory mites and lacewings to manage thrips populations.

insects.name: Grape Berry Moth
insects.effect: Larvae feed inside berries causing fruit rot and yield loss.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Fom honeydew, leading to sooty mold and reducing vine vigor.

insects.name: Phylloxera
insects.effect: Root-feeding forms stunt vines and cause yellowing.

solution: Use mating disruption pheromones or targeted insecticides timed to egg hatch.
Introduce natural parasitoids (e.g., Anagyrus pseudococci) to suppress mealybugs.
Plant phylloxera-resistant rootstocks and maintain clean planting material.

insects.name: Codling Moth
insects.effect: Larvae burrow into fruit, causing wormy apples.

insects.name: Apple Maggot
insects.effect: Tunnels through fruit, making it unmarketable.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Distortion of leaves and shoots, and honeydew leads to sooty mold.

solution: Deploy pheromone traps and spray insecticide at biofix and peak flight.
Hang sticky traps and timely sprays before egg hatch for apple maggot.
Encourage predatory insects and treat aphid outbreaks with horticultural oils.

insects.name: Hornworm
insects.effect: Large caterpillars defoliate plants and eat fruits.

insects.name: Whitefly
insects.effect: Sap-feeding leads to honeydew and virus transmission.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Distort new growth and vector plant viruses.

solution: Handpick hornworms or use Bt sprays.
Apply yellow sticky traps and introduce Encarsia parasitoids for whitefly control.
Use insecticidal soap or oils early for aphid outbreaks and support beneficial insects.

insects.name: Onion Thrips
insects.effect: Scarring on leaves reduces photosynthesis and bulb size.

insects.name: Leek Moth
insects.effect: Larvae damage leaves and bulbs causing rot.

insects.name: Bulb Mites
insects.effect: Feed on bulbs leading to decay and yield loss.

solution: Monitor thrips and apply reflective mulch and insecticides at threshold.
Remove crop residues to disrupt leek moth life cycle.
Ensure clean seed and avoid planting in infested soil to reduce bulb mites.

insects.name: Southern Corn Rootworm
insects.effect: Larvae feed on underground nuts causing yield loss.

insects.name: Tobacco Thrips
insects.effect: Feed on seedlings causing stunting and reduced stands.

insects.name: Peanut Caterpillar
insects.effect: Defoliates foliage reducing photosynthesis.

solution: Use crop rotation and avoid continuous peanut planting.
Treat seeds with systemic insecticide to protect against seedling thrips.
Scout and apply foliar insecticides when defoliation exceeds 30%.

insects.name: Sugarcane Borer
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel stalks causing broken tops and yield loss.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Transmits viruses and weakens crop through sap loss.

insects.name: White Grubs
insects.effect: Damage roots reducing tillering and yield.

solution: Use resistant cultivars and maintain field sanitation.
Apply systemic insecticides at planting to manage aphids.
Rotate with non-host crops to reduce white grub populations.

insects.name: Cabbage Looper
insects.effect: Chews large holes in leaves reducing marketable head size.

insects.name: Diamondback Moth
insects.effect: Larvae skeletonize leaves and bore into heads.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cause curling, stunting, and sooty mold.

solution: Introduce Trichogramma wasps and use Bt sprays for loopers.
Use floating row covers early and apply insecticides targeting larvae.
Spray insecticidal soap and encourage beneficial insects to manage aphids.

insects.name: Sap Beetle
insects.effect: Feeds on damaged fruit causing rot and contamination.

insects.name: Strawberry Root Weevil
insects.effect: Larvae feed on roots causing wilt and reduced vigor.

insects.name: Twospotted Spider Mite
insects.effect: Feeds on undersides of leaves causing stippling and bronzing.

solution: Harvest promptly, remove damaged fruit and apply insecticide if beetles are abundant.
Use entomopathogenic nematodes and drench soil to control root weevil larvae.
Maintain humidity and apply miticides before mite populations explode.

insects.name: Sorghum Aphid
insects.effect: Rapidly multiplies, sucks sap causing stunting, yellowing, and can cause whole-plant death.

insects.name: Corn Leaf Aphid
insects.effect: Feeds in whorls, secretes honeydew, may stunt seedlings and reduce seed weight if mixed with sorghum aphid.

insects.name: Sorghum Shoot Fly
insects.effect: Larvae feed on growing shoots causing deadheart and reduced stands.

solution: Plant resistant hybrids to Biotype E greenbug and sorghum aphid and use timely planting dates ([turn0search0]).
Conserve natural enemies like lady beetles, syrphid larvae, parasitic wasps, and nabid bugs; apply insecticide only at economic thresholds ([turn0search0], [turn0search12]).
Use seed treatments or foliar insecticides if aphid populations cause seedling stunting; monitor and spray for shoot fly based on trap counts or larvae presence ([turn0search6], [turn0search21]).

insects.name: Tea Mosquito Bug
insects.effect: Pierces shoots and young leaves leading to chlorosis, dieback and yield loss.

insects.name: Red Spider Mite
insects.effect: Feeds on leaf undersides causing bronzing, defoliation, and reduced yield.

insects.name: Thrips
insects.effect: Scrape plant cells causing silvering, distortion and vector viruses.

solution: Prune shade to reduce mite habitats, and apply miticide when densities exceed threshold ([turn0search13], [turn0search19]).
Encourage natural predators (spiders, predatory mites) and rotate insecticides to prevent resistance ([turn0search5], [turn0search13]).
Maintain clean field sanitation and apply contact insecticides or spinosad early in infestation; use exclusion screens in nurseries ([turn0search7], [turn0search1]).

insects.name: Shoot Fly
insects.effect: Larvae feed on central shoots causing 'deadheart' and crop loss.

insects.name: Corn Leaf Aphid
insects.effect: Sucks sap, secretes honeydew, and can reduce yield, especially when virus is vectored.

insects.name: Indian Grain Aphid
insects.effect: Sap-feeding leading to stunted growth in cereals.

solution: Plant resistant varieties and adjust planting dates to avoid peak shoot fly periods; monitor with bait traps ([turn0search21]).
Conserve aphid predators; use insecticides only if stunting or honeydew damage exceeds threshold ([turn0search10], [turn0search12]).
Monitor for Indian grain aphid and apply threshold-based control only when significant sap damage observed ([turn0search25]).

insects.name: Banana Weevil
insects.effect: Larvae bore into rhizomes causing plant weakening and toppling.

insects.name: Banana Aphid
insects.effect: Transmits Banana Bunchy Top Virus; causes leaf curling and stunted growth.

solution: Use healthy suckers and destroy infested plants. Apply neem-based insecticides near the base.
Control aphids using yellow sticky traps, natural predators, and systemic insecticides when virus symptoms appear.

insects.name: Papaya Mealybug
insects.effect: Feeds on sap causing yellowing, sooty mold, and stunted fruiting.

insects.name: Red Spider Mite
insects.effect: Sucks sap from underside of leaves causing bronzing and defoliation.

solution: Use neem oil sprays or biological control with parasitoid wasps.
Spray miticides or maintain adequate irrigation to reduce spider mite incidence.

insects.name: Shoot and Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Larvae bore into shoots and fruits, causing wilting and damaged produce.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cause leaf curling and act as virus vectors.

solution: Remove and destroy infested shoots/fruits. Use pheromone traps and apply neem or Bt sprays.
Introduce ladybird beetles and use soap-based sprays for aphid suppression.

insects.name: Red Pumpkin Beetle
insects.effect: Feeds on leaves and flowers; grubs attack roots and fruits.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Lays eggs in fruits; larvae cause internal rotting.

solution: Apply ash and neem cake around base; use trap crops like bottle gourd.
Use bait traps with methyl eugenol and remove infested fruits regularly.

insects.name: Jassids
insects.effect: Suck sap causing yellowing, leaf curling and poor pod formation.

insects.name: Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Larvae bore into fruits making them unmarketable.

solution: Spray neem extract or use resistant varieties like Arka Anamika.
Use pheromone traps and remove affected fruits promptly.

insects.name: Carrot Rust Fly
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel into roots causing black lines and rot.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Transmit viruses and cause stunted growth.

solution: Use floating row covers and practice crop rotation.
Control aphids early with insecticidal soaps or neem spray.

insects.name: Cabbage Looper
insects.effect: Chews large holes in leaves and heads.

insects.name: Diamondback Moth
insects.effect: Larvae feed on leaves and bore into curds.

solution: Spray Bt formulations or neem oil regularly during early growth.
Encourage natural predators like birds and parasitoid wasps.

insects.name: Flea Beetle
insects.effect: Makes shot holes in leaves; larvae can attack roots.

insects.name: Root Maggot
insects.effect: Larvae feed inside roots causing soft rotting and yield loss.

solution: Use sticky traps and apply ash or diatomaceous earth around base.
Avoid overwatering and use crop rotation with non-host crops.

insects.name: Leaf Miner
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel within leaves forming whitish mines reducing quality.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cause leaf curling and transmit viruses.

solution: Remove infested leaves; apply neem oil or Spinosad.
Introduce beneficial insects like lacewings or lady beetles.

insects.name: Beet Leafminer
insects.effect: Larvae mine between leaf surfaces making the crop unmarketable.

insects.name: Cutworms
insects.effect: Sever young plants at soil level during night feeding.

solution: Use row covers to block egg-laying and remove mined leaves.
Apply biological controls like nematodes or Bacillus thuringiensis at seedling stage.

insects.name: Mustard Aphid
insects.effect: Sucks sap from tender parts, causing curling, stunted growth and poor seed set.

insects.name: Painted Bug
insects.effect: Feeds on sap and seeds; causes shriveling of pods and yield loss.

solution: Spray neem oil early and introduce predatory insects like lady beetles.
Apply systemic insecticides at flowering if aphid count exceeds economic threshold.

insects.name: Pea Stem Fly
insects.effect: Larvae bore into stems causing wilting and hollow stems.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Transmit mosaic viruses and cause leaf distortion.

solution: Use seed treatment with systemic insecticides to prevent early damage.
Spray neem extract or imidacloprid at early flowering stage if aphid pressure is high.

insects.name: Thrips
insects.effect: Scrape the leaf surface causing curling and silvery appearance.

insects.name: Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Larvae bore into fruits rendering them unfit for market.

solution: Apply neem-based insecticides and maintain field sanitation.
Install pheromone traps and spray Spinosad when infestation is noticed.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cause yellowing and curling; act as vectors of viral diseases.

insects.name: Cutworms
insects.effect: Feed at night, cutting young seedlings at ground level.

solution: Use light traps to monitor moths and apply ash around the base of plants.
Spray neem oil or introduce natural enemies like lacewings for aphid control.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cluster on young leaves and stems, sucking sap and reducing vigor.

insects.name: White Grubs
insects.effect: Feed on roots, leading to yellowing and wilting of plants.

solution: Apply neem cake to the soil and maintain weed-free conditions.
Use systemic insecticides in case of severe infestation.

insects.name: Thrips
insects.effect: Feed on foliage causing silvering, drying and curling of leaves.

insects.name: Onion Fly
insects.effect: Maggots attack the bulbs causing rotting.

solution: Use reflective mulch and apply insecticides at threshold levels.
Remove affected plants and use crop rotation to break pest cycle.

insects.name: Shoot Borer
insects.effect: Larvae bore into pseudostems causing yellowing and wilting.

insects.name: Rhizome Scale
insects.effect: Sucks sap from rhizomes, leading to shrinkage and poor sprouting.

solution: Drench with neem extract and maintain adequate drainage.
Use clean planting material and solarize beds before planting.

insects.name: Rhizome Fly
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel into rhizomes causing internal decay and yield loss.

insects.name: Shoot Borer
insects.effect: Causes dead heart by boring into central shoots.

solution: Remove and destroy infested rhizomes.
Apply neem-based sprays and maintain proper spacing to reduce humidity.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Larvae develop inside fruits causing internal rotting.

insects.name: Red Pumpkin Beetle
insects.effect: Adults feed on foliage, grubs damage roots and fruits.

solution: Install methyl eugenol traps and remove infested fruits.
Use ash or neem cake at base and spray neem oil on leaves.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Feed on sap, cause stunted growth and transmit mosaic viruses.

insects.name: Spider Mites
insects.effect: Cause stippling, leaf bronzing and defoliation.

solution: Spray insecticidal soap and introduce natural predators like ladybugs.
Use sulfur-based miticides in case of heavy mite infestation.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Eggs laid in fruit lead to larval feeding and internal decay.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cause curling of young leaves and spread viral diseases.

solution: Use methyl eugenol traps and remove infested fruits promptly.
Spray neem oil and encourage beneficial insects like lacewings for aphid control.

insects.name: Red Pumpkin Beetle
insects.effect: Feeds on cotyledons and young leaves; grubs attack roots.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Larvae damage fruits from inside causing decay.

solution: Use ash and neem cake around roots and install bait traps.
Apply neem oil sprays and dispose of damaged fruits regularly.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Bores into fruits making them unfit for consumption.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Suck sap from leaves and fruits leading to sooty mold.

solution: Bagging of fruits and use of pheromone traps for fruit fly control.
Apply neem-based sprays and support natural enemies like ladybird beetles.

insects.name: Pomegranate Butterfly (Anar Butterfly)
insects.effect: Larvae bore into fruits causing internal rotting.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Distort leaves and reduce flowering.

solution: Bag fruits and use light traps; apply contact insecticides if needed.
Spray neem oil and promote beneficial insects like hoverflies.

insects.name: Leaf Miner
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel inside leaves, causing serpentine mines and curling.

insects.name: Citrus Psylla
insects.effect: Sucks sap, transmits greening disease (HLB).

solution: Prune affected shoots and spray neem or horticultural oil.
Apply imidacloprid-based sprays and remove infected trees to control psylla.

insects.name: Mango Hopper
insects.effect: Sucks sap from inflorescence causing flower drop.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Infests fruits causing rotting and drop.

solution: Spray neem oil during flowering and use light traps.
Use methyl eugenol traps and destroy fallen infested fruits.

insects.name: Red Pumpkin Beetle
insects.effect: Damages foliage and flowers, reducing fruit setting.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Larvae cause internal fruit damage and rotting.

solution: Apply neem oil regularly and place bait traps for adult flies.
Remove affected fruits and maintain field hygiene.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Suck sap causing leaf curling and virus transmission.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Bores into fruits causing deformation and rot.

solution: Use yellow sticky traps and neem sprays for aphid control.
Bag young fruits and use pheromone traps for fruit fly monitoring.

insects.name: Jassids
insects.effect: Cause leaf cupping, discoloration and reduce photosynthesis.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Affects developing fruits leading to internal damage.

solution: Introduce neem-based sprays and manage weeds around field borders.
Apply bait traps and remove damaged fruits from the field.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Suck sap and transmit mosaic viruses.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Leads to rotting and premature drop of fruits.

solution: Use neem oil and biological control agents like coccinellids.
Install pheromone traps and destroy affected fruits regularly.

insects.name: Sweet Potato Weevil
insects.effect: Larvae bore into tubers and stems, causing yield loss and tuber rot.

insects.name: Whitefly
insects.effect: Sucks sap and transmits leaf curl viruses.

solution: Use clean planting material, destroy crop residues, and apply pheromone traps.
Spray neem oil and introduce parasitoids like Encarsia for whitefly control.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Attach to stems and leaves, sucking sap and weakening the plant.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Cause stunted growth and lead to sooty mold formation.

solution: Apply neem or fish oil resin soap sprays and destroy infected vines.
Encourage natural predators like ladybird beetles and avoid excess nitrogen fertilization.

insects.name: Flea Beetles
insects.effect: Make small holes in leaves and affect root development.

insects.name: Cutworms
insects.effect: Sever seedlings at the base leading to poor stand establishment.

solution: Use row covers and trap crops like mustard to lure beetles.
Apply ash or neem powder around plant base; irrigate early to reduce cutworm activity.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cause leaf curling and yellowing, reducing growth rate.

insects.name: Leaf Webber
insects.effect: Larvae web leaves together and feed inside, reducing leaf quality.

solution: Spray neem oil or garlic extract and encourage beneficial insects.
Remove webbed leaves and apply biopesticides like Bt or Spinosad.

insects.name: Cabbage Worm
insects.effect: Feeds on foliage and bores into heads, making them unfit for market.

insects.name: Flea Beetle
insects.effect: Makes small shot holes in leaves, affecting photosynthesis.

solution: Apply Bt spray during early stages and maintain field sanitation.
Use floating row covers and rotate crops with non-hosts.

insects.name: Cabbage Looper
insects.effect: Chews large irregular holes in leaves and heads.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cluster on underside of leaves, causing yellowing and reduced head size.

solution: Spray Bt or neem oil during early crop stages.
Use soap sprays and encourage lacewings for aphid control.

insects.name: Leaf Miner
insects.effect: Creates winding mines in leaves reducing market value.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Suck sap and transmit viral diseases.

solution: Use row covers to block egg laying and spray neem oil.
Apply insecticidal soap and remove heavily infested leaves.

insects.name: Carrot Fly
insects.effect: Larvae feed on roots, causing tunneling and rot.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cause leaf curling and reduce vigor.

solution: Use floating row covers and plant resistant varieties.
Apply neem spray or introduce predatory insects like ladybugs.

insects.name: Armyworm
insects.effect: Feeds on leaves causing defoliation.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Suck sap, deform leaves and attract ants.

solution: Handpick larvae early and use Spinosad for severe infestations.
Spray neem oil and release lacewings or parasitic wasps.

insects.name: Leek Moth
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel into leaves and bulbs causing rot.

insects.name: Thrips
insects.effect: Feed on foliage, causing silvery streaks and leaf twisting.

solution: Use pheromone traps for early detection and destroy infested debris.
Spray miticides or neem extract and ensure good field airflow.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Lays eggs in fruit; maggots feed inside, causing internal rotting.

insects.name: Leaf Webber
insects.effect: Webs leaves and feeds inside, reducing photosynthesis.

solution: Use methyl eugenol traps and remove fallen infested fruits.
Prune infested shoots and apply neem oil or Bt-based spray.

insects.name: Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Larvae bore into ripening fruits, making them unfit for consumption.

insects.name: Leaf Defoliator
insects.effect: Feeds on foliage, reducing tree vigor and productivity.

solution: Collect and destroy infested fruits; spray contact insecticides pre-harvest.
Use light traps and neem sprays to manage defoliators.

insects.name: Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Larvae damage pulp internally, leading to fruit drop and rot.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Suck sap from leaves and stems; cause yellowing and mold growth.

solution: Bag fruits and apply botanical sprays during fruit development.
Introduce predators like ladybird beetles and spray neem oil.

insects.name: Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Larvae bore into tender fruits causing rot and unmarketability.

insects.name: Shoot Borer
insects.effect: Affects tender shoots leading to drying and distorted growth.

solution: Remove and destroy infested fruits; apply systemic insecticides when needed.
Maintain proper canopy airflow and apply neem-based sprays.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Eggs hatch inside fruit leading to soft rot and foul smell.

insects.name: Leaf Roller
insects.effect: Rolls and feeds inside leaves, lowering tree vitality.

solution: Use pheromone traps and remove damaged fruits early.
Spray neem or Spinosad and prune infected shoots.

insects.name: Leaf Miner
insects.effect: Creates serpentine mines on leaves reducing photosynthetic efficiency.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Lead to leaf yellowing, branch drying and sooty mold formation.

solution: Apply horticultural oils and prune heavily infested branches.
Use sticky traps and neem soap during early infestations.

insects.name: Pod Borer
insects.effect: Damages developing pods leading to seed exposure and drop.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Attach to branches and suck sap, leading to poor flowering.

solution: Apply light insecticide sprays before flowering; remove and destroy infested pods.
Use horticultural mineral oil and encourage natural predators.

insects.name: Shoot Gall Maker
insects.effect: Causes gall formation on shoots, disrupting growth.

insects.name: Bark Eating Caterpillar
insects.effect: Feeds on bark and creates galleries, weakening branches.

solution: Remove galls and apply systemic insecticides during active periods.
Close caterpillar holes with kerosene-soaked cotton and seal with mud.

insects.name: Peach Fruit Moth
insects.effect: Infests fruits internally causing premature drop and rot.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Cluster on shoots causing leaf curl and stunted growth.

solution: Spray Spinosad or neem extract during early fruit development.
Apply soap sprays or imidacloprid at early infestation stage.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Infests ripening fruits leading to poor shelf life.

insects.name: Leaf Curl Aphid
insects.effect: Distorts young leaves, affecting fruit formation.

solution: Use fruit fly traps and harvest fruits at appropriate maturity.
Control aphids with neem sprays and promote natural predators.

insects.name: Codling Moth
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel into fruits, leaving frass and making them unmarketable.

insects.name: Pear Psylla
insects.effect: Sucks sap and secretes honeydew leading to sooty mold.

solution: Apply pheromone traps and insect growth regulators (IGRs).
Spray neem oil and prune infested shoots early in the season.

insects.name: Fig Borer
insects.effect: Bores into stems and fruits, causing wilting and internal decay.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Sap feeders that weaken the plant and promote fungal growth.

solution: Remove and burn infested branches; use light traps.
Apply horticultural oil sprays and encourage parasitic wasps.

insects.name: Litchi Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Damages developing fruits leading to shriveling and drop.

insects.name: Leaf Curl Mite
insects.effect: Causes curling and bronzing of leaves, reducing photosynthesis.

solution: Bag fruits at early stages and apply neem-based sprays.
Use sulfur sprays or miticides for controlling mites.

insects.name: Grape Berry Moth
insects.effect: Larvae bore into berries leading to rotting and fungal infection.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Cause fruit drop, mold formation and vine weakening.

solution: Use pheromone traps and remove infested bunches.
Spray neem oil or introduce predatory beetles like Cryptolaemus montrouzieri.

insects.name: Avocado Thrips
insects.effect: Scars fruit surface, reducing market value.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Lays eggs in ripening fruits causing internal rotting.

solution: Monitor with yellow sticky traps and spray Spinosad if needed.
Collect and destroy fallen fruits regularly.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Transmits wilt virus and weakens the plant.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Feed on leaves and crown, reducing plant vigor.

solution: Dip suckers in insecticidal solution before planting.
Apply horticultural oil sprays and encourage predatory insects.

insects.name: Spider Mites
insects.effect: Cause leaf bronzing, webbing and fruit shrinkage.

insects.name: Strawberry Root Weevil
insects.effect: Larvae feed on roots, reducing plant growth.

solution: Spray sulfur-based miticides and maintain field hygiene.
Use biological control with entomopathogenic nematodes.

insects.name: Blueberry Maggot

insects.name: Fruit Fly

insects.name: Mealybugs

insects.name: Fruit Borer

insects.name: Fruit Fly

insects.effect: Damages internal pulp leading to fruit rotting.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Suck plant sap leading to black sooty mold and reduced fruit size.

solution: Bag fruits to prevent entry and destroy infected ones.
Apply neem spray and manage ants that protect mealybugs.

insects.name: Shoot Borer
insects.effect: Larvae bore into young shoots, leading to drying and stunted growth.

insects.name: Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Feeds on immature fruits causing internal decay.

solution: Remove and destroy affected shoots and apply neem oil spray.
Use biological control like Trichogramma wasps.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Cause stunted growth and promote fungal growth.

insects.name: Thrips
insects.effect: Cause silvery patches on leaves and hinder fruit development.

solution: Ensure clean planting material and apply neem oil during early growth.
Promote biological control with ladybird beetles and parasitoids.

insects.name: Litchi Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Feeds inside fruits leading to decay and drop.

insects.name: Leaf Curl Mite
insects.effect: Causes curling of leaves and reduction in photosynthesis.

solution: Bag fruits and spray neem oil pre-flowering.
Prune and burn affected leaves; apply sulfur-based sprays if mites persist.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Leads to early fruit drop and internal rotting.

insects.name: Lac Insect
insects.effect: Forms encrustations on twigs weakening plant growth.

solution: Use fly traps and remove fallen fruits promptly.
Apply neem-based sprays and prune infested branches.

insects.name: Shoot Borer
insects.effect: Damages new shoots and stunts plant growth.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Lays eggs in ripening fruits causing rot.

solution: Spray neem oil during new flush and prune affected twigs.
Use methyl eugenol traps and maintain orchard sanitation.

insects.name: Fig Borer
insects.effect: Bores into branches and fruits leading to decay.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Cause yellowing of leaves and weakening of plants.

solution: Apply neem oil and prune infected branches early.
Use systemic insecticides for severe infestations and encourage predatory beetles.

insects.name: Avocado Thrips
insects.effect: Cause scarring on developing fruits and silvering of leaves.

insects.name: Red Spider Mites
insects.effect: Suck sap from leaves, leading to bronzing and early leaf fall.

solution: Apply neem oil sprays during early fruit development.
Encourage predatory mites and maintain orchard hygiene.

insects.name: Olive Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Larvae feed inside the fruit, causing premature drop and reduced oil quality.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Weaken branches and reduce yield by sucking sap.

solution: Use pheromone traps and harvest fruits early.
Apply horticultural oil and introduce parasitoids.

insects.name: Citrus Leaf Miner
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel into leaves causing distortion and reduced growth.

insects.name: Black Citrus Aphid
insects.effect: Cause leaf curling and act as a vector for viral diseases.

solution: Prune infested shoots and spray neem seed extract weekly.
Use yellow sticky traps and encourage lacewings.

insects.name: Citrus Psylla
insects.effect: Transmits greening disease and causes shoot curling.

insects.name: Whiteflies
insects.effect: Lead to honeydew secretion and black sooty mold.

solution: Spray neem-based products and release natural predators.
Prune infested parts and monitor regularly with traps.

insects.name: Citrus Aphids
insects.effect: Suck sap from tender parts and distort growth.

insects.name: Leaf Miner
insects.effect: Cause silvery trails in leaves reducing photosynthesis.

solution: Spray neem oil and install yellow sticky traps.
Encourage parasitic wasps for miner control.

insects.name: Bark Eating Caterpillar
insects.effect: Larvae feed on bark, weakening branches and stems.

insects.name: Shoot Gall Maker
insects.effect: Causes gall formation on shoots and stunted growth.

solution: Scrape and apply neem-based paste on trunks.
Prune and destroy affected twigs before monsoon.

insects.name: Fruit Borer
insects.effect: Bores into developing pods causing damage to seeds.

insects.name: Aphids
insects.effect: Lead to yellowing and distorted leaves.

solution: Remove fallen pods and use neem-based sprays during flowering.
Install sticky traps and maintain clean orchard floor.

insects.name: Fruit Fly
insects.effect: Infests fruits causing internal rotting.

insects.name: Leaf Roller
insects.effect: Rolls and feeds inside leaves reducing foliage health.

solution: Use pheromone traps and remove infested fruits regularly.
Spray neem extract and avoid dense canopy formation.

insects.name: Pod Fly
insects.effect: Infests developing pods leading to premature drop.

insects.name: Hairy Caterpillar
insects.effect: Feeds on leaves causing complete defoliation.

solution: Install pheromone traps and destroy infected pods.
Use neem oil spray during vegetative growth and maintain sanitation.

insects.name: Rhinoceros Beetle
insects.effect: Bores into crown and damages internal tissue.

insects.name: Red Palm Weevil
insects.effect: Larvae bore into trunk causing weakening and possible tree death.

solution: Use pheromone traps and destroy infected palms.
Apply neem cake and chlorantraniliprole-based pesticides in bore holes.

insects.name: Spindle Bug
insects.effect: Sucks sap from young spindle leaves causing yellow streaks and drying.

insects.name: Root Grubs
insects.effect: Feed on roots causing yellowing and wilting of palms.

solution: Apply neem-based insecticides in the leaf axils regularly.
Drench soil with chlorpyrifos and apply neem cake around roots.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Cause yellowing and reduced leaf quality.

insects.name: Mites
insects.effect: Lead to leaf curling and poor texture.

solution: Spray neem oil or sulfur-based miticides.
Maintain high humidity and remove infested leaves.

insects.name: Teak Defoliator
insects.effect: Larvae feed on foliage leading to defoliation.

insects.name: Skeletonizer
insects.effect: Feeds on green leaf tissues leaving only veins.

solution: Apply biopesticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).
Use light traps and conserve parasitoids like Trichogramma.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Suck sap from leaves and stems, reducing growth.

insects.name: Leaf Webber
insects.effect: Webs and feeds on young leaves reducing photosynthesis.

solution: Spray neem oil and prune affected parts.
Encourage natural predators and maintain tree spacing.

insects.name: Gall Wasp
insects.effect: Causes galls on shoots and leaves, reducing growth rate.

insects.name: Leaf Beetle
insects.effect: Feeds on leaf surface causing defoliation.

solution: Remove and destroy galled shoots regularly.
Spray neem oil or use systemic insecticides during early attack.

insects.name: Shoot Borer
insects.effect: Bores into young culms and causes drying.

insects.name: Leaf Roller
insects.effect: Rolls and feeds on leaves reducing photosynthesis.

solution: Apply neem spray on emerging shoots.
Remove and burn infested shoots and maintain spacing.

insects.name: Stem Borer
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel into trunks and branches causing dieback.

insects.name: Leaf Miner
insects.effect: Creates blotches in leaves and reduces photosynthetic capacity.

solution: Apply insecticides in bore holes and prune dead branches.
Use sticky traps and neem oil spray during early stages.

insects.name: Tea Mosquito Bug
insects.effect: Causes necrotic patches on young shoots, flowers, and nuts.

insects.name: Stem and Root Borer
insects.effect: Larvae bore into bark causing girdling and tree death.

solution: Spray lambda-cyhalothrin during flushing and flowering stages.
Remove infested trees and apply Bordeaux paste on wounds.

insects.name: Coffee White Stem Borer
insects.effect: Larvae tunnel through stem weakening plant and reducing yield.

insects.name: Berry Borer
insects.effect: Infests berries causing blackened, hollow beans.

solution: Apply chlorpyrifos to stems and use pheromone traps.
Shade regulation and regular pruning help reduce infestations.

insects.name: Tea Mosquito Bug
insects.effect: Feeds on young shoots and buds causing blackening and drop.

insects.name: Red Spider Mite
insects.effect: Leads to bronzing of leaves and reduced leaf production.

solution: Spray neem-based miticides and maintain shade trees.
Encourage predatory mites and avoid drought stress.

insects.name: Scale Insects
insects.effect: Cause yellowing and poor latex yield.

insects.name: Leaf Roller
insects.effect: Webs and folds leaves affecting photosynthesis.

solution: Use neem oil or soap sprays for minor infestations.
Apply systemic insecticides and remove infested parts.

insects.name: Leaf Roller
insects.effect: Feeds on leaves by rolling them, reducing quality for silkworms.

insects.name: Mealybugs
insects.effect: Suck sap and weaken the plant leading to defoliation.

solution: Spray neem extract and maintain clean cultivation practices.
Prune and destroy infested branches and control ant movement.
